div.p: Ordered, THAT John Otis & Paul Dudley Eſqrs give the Thanks of the Board to the Reverend Mr. Nathanael Stone, for his SERMON Preached before the GENERAL ASSEMBLY, and deſire a Copy thereof in order to its being Printed.
RULERS Are a Terror, Not to good, but Evil-workers.
A SERMON Preached before His Excellency Samuel Shute Eſq His Majeſty's COUNCIL, and the Repreſentatives of the Province of the Maſſachuſetts-Bay in New-England, on May 25, 1720.
On the Day of ELECTION of His Majeſty's COUNCIL there.
By NATHANAEL STONE, Paſtor of a Congregation in Harwich.
BOSTON in N. E.
Printed by B. Green, Printer to His Excellency the GOVERNOUR and COUNCIL 1720.

div.head: An Election SERMON.

epigraph.q: For Rulers are not a terror to Good Works, but to the Evil.

div.p: THAT this Epiſtle was written to a Number of Chriſtians in Rome is unqueſtionable. Whither it was written to a Church there ſeems not evident.

THE former part of the Epiſtle is Doctrinal; and it treats of the moſt important Doctrines of the Goſpel; as GOD'S eternal Purpoſe, Fore-knowledge, Predeſtination, Vocation of Sinners into a State of Grace, their Juſtification there-upon, &c. The Doctrine of Juſtification is here very particularly and clearly handled, by the Apoſtle.

THE latter part of the Epiſtle is Practical, Inſtructive of us as to variety of Duties to be done by us. Within this part falls this Chapter, and particularly this Text; For
Rulers are not a terror to good works; but to the Evil.

IN v. 1. We have a Divine Command given by the Mouth of an Apoſtle, viz. Let every Soul be ſubject unto the higher Powers. The Soul is here put for the Perſon, as frequently other-where in Scripture. Every Soul, includes Perſons of all Ranks and Diſtinctions. Powers, are here intended of Civil Rulers; for the Apoſtle is not here treating of Churchgovernment.

OBEDIENCE to this Precept is here urged by weighty Reaſons. GOD made Man a Rational Being; and as ſuch He deals with him. He expects he ſhould be ſwayed by Reaſon; and accordingly he is hereby preſſed to his Duty.
AND He tells us,

1. THAT the Powers are of GOD. They are Ordained by Him, are Conſtituted by His Authority. And this ſhould certainly be of weight with Rational Beings, with every Man that owns a GOD, and himſelf to be His Creature, ſuſtained by Him every Moment, and deriving from Him every thing, every good thing that is injoyed by him.

2. THAT whoſoever reſiſts the Power, reſiſts the Ordinance of GOD. He does not ultimately
reſiſt a Creature, but GOD Himſelf, while he reſiſts, or oppoſes himſelf againſt His Ordinance. He wages War with GOD Himſelf. And what daring Madneſs is this in the Creature! Who is, as we read, in Jer. 18.6. In GOD'S Hand as the clay is in the Potters hand.

3. THAT they that reſiſt, ſhall receive to themſelves Damnation. A dreadful doom indeed! A ſtrong Motive it is to be ſubject to Government. Its the ſame word both in the Tranſlation and Original, which we read, in 1 Cor. 11. 29. reſpecting Perſons Unworthily receiving the Lords Supper. And tho' it be true that the word might be tranſlated, Judgment; its alſo true, That either of theſe Sins, with all others that Men are guilty of, or any particular Sin whatſoever; without Repentance, will iſſue in Damnation.

4.(WHICH brings me to my Text) he tells us, That Rulers are not a terror to good works, but to the evil. q. d. Obey them, Chearfully ſubmit to their Authority and Rule; for tho' they be Men armed with the Sword of Civil Juſtice; they are only evil workers, vicious Perſons, to whom they are a terror. They will not hurt the good: No, their Power is, as is the Law, in 1 Tim. 1.9. Not againſt a Righteous Man, but againſt the Lawleſs, Diſobedient, Ungodly, Unholy, &c.
IN the Words of the Text we have,

1. THE ſubject ſpoken of, viz. Rulers; Such to whom the Civil Government is by GOD committed; they are Rulers, Ruling in the Fear of GOD; Rulers in Scripture denominated gods. Pſal. 82.1. GOD judgeth among the gods: they are gods, as being cloathed with His Authority; gods, as bearing the lively Image of His own Impartiality, Equity, Juſtice, &c. mixed with Lenity and Mercy.
2. WHAT is Predicated or Affirmed of them. They are a Terror. Their Countenances, Deportments, and Adminiſtrations carry a terror in them.

3. TO whom they are thus, or the objects of this Terror of theirs. And they are thus, (1) Negatively, Not to good works. Here works are put for Perſons working. Rulers are no terror to them that be honeſt and good; that do good & work righteouſneſs. (2) Poſitively, They are a terror to evil works. i. e. To evil workers. Evil workers, Vicious Perſons, are they to whom they are a terror. Againſt theſe it is that the Point, of their Sword of Civil Juſtice is ſet. Immoral Men, Men of evil Practices, of wicked Lives, are the objects of their terror. Thus are Rulers a terror not to good works, but to the evil,
DOCTRINE. THEY are Evil Workers, Vicious Perſons, to whom Rulers are a Terror.

TO theſe and only theſe, according to their Character in my Text, they are ſo. They are Evil Workers againſt whom their faces are ſet, and the edge of their Authority turned. They will not hurt the good: No, Rom. 13.3. Do good, and thou ſhalt have praiſe of them. They will not diſcoutenance, but incourage the doing of Good. This you may expect; for we read in Rom. 13.4. The Civil Ruler is the Miniſter of GOD unto thee for good.
FOR further Illuſtration of this Truth, I ſhall firſt lay down the following Poſitions; then Anſwer the Inquiry, viz. How, or in what way are Rulers a terror to Evil Workers, to Vicious Livers?
POSITIONS.

Poſition, 1. That RULE Originally belongs to GOD Only. The right of Rule is Primarily alone in the Hand of the High and Lofty ONE, who inhabiteth Eternity. Even a proud and lofty ſpirited Heathen ſeems to
have been convinced of this, in Dan. 4.34—I praiſed and honoured Him that liveth for ever, whoſe Dominion is an everlaſting Dominion, and his Kingdom from Generation to Generation. And it will come to that again, that all Rule ſhall be intirely in the Hand of the Great JEHOVAH. We read, in 1 Cor. 15.24. That the Great Mediator ſhall put down all Rule, Authority, and Power; and then ſhall deliver up the Kingdom to GOD. And v. 28. When all things ſhall be ſubdued unto the Son; the Son Himſelf ſhall be ſubject to Him that put all things under Him; that GOD may be all in all.

Poſition, 2. RULE being a Communicable Property of GOD, it may be derived unto His Creatures. Creatures may by participation be inveſted with Rule and Government, which be Originally in GOD alone. As Holineſs, Juſtice, Goodneſs, &c. are communicable Properties of GOD: ſo is Dominion alſo.

Poſition, 3. IT was accordingly communicated to Adam in Innocency. To him was given Dominion over every Sublunary Being. GOD cloathed him in a degree with His own Authority. Gen. 1.28. — Have Dominion over the Fiſh of the Sea, the Fowl of the Air, and over every living thing that moveth on the
Earth. And in this Dominion ſeems the Image of GOD on Adam, in part to have conſiſted. It was indeed Righteouſneſs and Holineſs in which it principally did conſiſt; but not excluſive of Rule and Government, with which he was betruſted.

Poſition, 4. A forfeiture was made by the fall of this as well as of all other good. Man by this Apoſtacy forfeited all his favours. He retained no title to any good at all; no right to any thing either profitable, pleaſurable, or honourable. To that deadly complicated death only, now he had a title: Gen. 2.17. —Thou ſhalt ſurely die. He was now not only ſtript of his right to Rule, as well as other benefits: but his condition was much worſe than that of curſed Canaan, Gen. 9.25. A Servant of Servants ſhall he be unto his Brethren.

Poſition, 5. GOD by common favour, on the Revelation of the Goſpel, reſtored Rule in ſome degree to fallen Man. This is undeniably evident from Scripture. Not only Rule, but Rule by Divine appointment, now belongs to fallen Man; to ſome in one kind, to others in another; to ſome in one degree, to others in another. And this is among GODS common favours: it belongs to bad as well as good Men. Its no diſtinguiſhing Character
of gracious Perſons from others of Mankind. No, Dominion is not founded in Grace. Even wicked Saul was the LORD'S Anointed: He had right to Rule in Iſrael, tho' he was totally, devoid of any ſaving good.

Poſition, 6. RULE is either common to Mankind in general; or appropriated more particularly unto Some of them. Common Rule belongs to Men as Men reſpited from preſent Ruine, and allowed to continue for a time in the World; to an ••• r the Ends that Infinite Wiſdom has de • ig •• d, with reſpect to them. This every Man is in ſome degree a ſharer in. The reſtoration of this to Apoſtate Man, we have the account of, in Gen, 9.2. And the fear of you, and the dread of you, ſhall be upon every beaſt of the earth, &c. Into your hand are they delivered. That Rule which is more Special, is either, (1) Natural, as that of Parents reſpecting Children. They have a Natural, tho' a limitted right of dominion over them; and Children are accordingly under a Natural tie to yield Obedience. (2) Civil Rule, including in it that which is Military alſo. (3) Eccleſiaſtical, which is ſetled in and over the viſible Church by CHRIST, as the King and Head of it. Eccleſiaſtical Rulers before the Moſaick Law, were the Firſt-born of the Families. Under the Law the Stated Rulers of the Church were the Prieſts and
Levites Since the Law, they are Apoſtles, Evangeliſts, Paſtors and Teachers.

BUT the Civil Rulers are they of whom my Text ſpeaks, and concerning whom it is affirmed; They are a Terror, not to good works, &c. They are evil workers, vicious perſons, to be a terror unto whom theſe are conſtituted by GOD. This by Divine appointment is their Office: And on this very thing they are to attend, Rom. 13.6.
QUESTION. BUT how, or whereby do Rulers become a Terror to Evil Workers, to Perſons of Vicious Lives, and Practices?
ANSWER. THEY are and appear to be a Terror to evil workers.

1. BY their very Countenances and Grave deportments. Perſons of ill Manners and baſe Practices may read in the very Countenances of Rulers, their ill-reſentment of them. Even therein may be read their hatred of them that work iniquity. We read, in Prov. 25.23. The North wind driveth away rain, ſo does an angry countenance, a backbiting Tongue.
Backbiting Tongues, and other baſe Practices, have the countenances of Rulers ſet againſt them. Nor are their Grave deportments, in their daily Converſation, without uſe and ſervice this way.

2. BY their manifeſt Averſion from Perſons of ill fame, and diſſolute Lives. They loath the practices of Vicious Perſons. As the Ruler in Iſrael: Pſal. 26.5. They hate the Congregation of evil-doers, and will not ſit with the wicked. They loath the works of them that turn aſide to Vicious Courſes. They are the faithful of the Land on whom they ſet their eyes; towards whom they manifeſt their countenances favourable. Pſal. 101.3, 6. Nor will they know, with approbation, any wicked Perſon.

3. BY Enacting Laws ſuited to the Suppreſſion of Immorality and Vice, and the incouragement of Equity and Virtue. The Laws of the Land ſhall be adapted by them to the great ends of incouraging them that do well, and the ſuppreſſion of evil Men, and evil Manners.

4. BY looking diligently to the Execution of them. Rulers will carefully ſee to it that the Laws anſwer their proper end; that they be not wreſted by evil men, to ſerve baſe deſigns, nor the uſe of them fruſtrated by ſuch as Study how to evade their force.

5. BY Rejecting with abhorrence, thoſe Men that would obtain, with Money, Places of Honour and Truſt. They will without any further inquiry determine ſuch Men unfit for any Publick Place or Station. Rulers know that its not Bribery but Virtue that makes Men ſit to repreſent, as Rulers do, the Perſon of the Son of GOD. Accordingly they will carefully avoid preferring Men to Publick Places, of baſe, fordid, ſelfiſh Spirits.

6. BY throwing out of Place Officers that be evidently Unfaithful to their Truſt. They will hear their teſtimony againſt Immorality, by diſplacing Unfaithful Officers. The Publick ſhall know that they are not Abetters of any ſuch Men. In this way they will make it known that their Practice is agreeable to their Character in my Text. Immoral Perſons ſhall be diveſted of their Offices, and diſmiſſed from their Places of Publick Truſt.

7. BY appointing Perſons to keep Publick Houſes, who are themſelves a terror to ſensual, ſloathful, vile and baſe Men. They will pick our Men in Towns for that Place, that be Men of Honeſty and Courage; Men that hate gain by the Sins of other Men; Men that will carefully obſerve the Laws reſpecting Taverns; that will diſcountenance Towndwellers,
and reſerve their Publick Houſes for ſuch for whom they are by Law deſigned, Men that regard the Intereſt of Religion, and prefer the Publick Weal above their Private Intereſt, ſhall be the Men for theſe betruſtments. Indeed there are few Men in the Province, that have greater advantages, either to prevent, or promote the Ruine of this People, than Tavern-keepers have.

8. Laſtly, BY giving proper Incouragement, and ſuitable Support to the Goſpel-Miniſtry. The direct end of that is not only to terrifie Evil-workers; but to eradicate Original Sin it ſelf, from whence all evil works proceed. Its direct tendency is to beat down the Devils Kingdom, and raſe the very root of Actual Sin. Accordingly we read, as in Act. 26.18.—I ſend thee to open mens eyes, to turn them from darkneſs to light, and from the power of Satan to GOD. Thus runs the Commiſſion given to the Goſpel Miniſtry. So in 2 Cor. 10.4. The weapons of our Warfare are not carnal, but mighty thro' GOD, for the pulling down of ſtrong holds. Theſe ſtrong holds are the obſtinate Wills of deeply depraved Men: and for the breaking down of theſe, to a ſubmiſſion to GOD's righteouſneſs, is the Goſpel Miniſtry appointed.

THE great end of Civil Government is, to reſtrain Mens Corruptions, to prevent Sin from breaking out to that degree to deluge the World; to damm up its Streams, that they may not as a mighty Torrent, carry all before them. This is the great end of Civil Laws, Penalties annexed to them, Puniſhments inflicted on Malefactors, &c. Theſe things are appointed of GOD as means to reſtrain Mens exorbitant Luſts.

BUT the tendency of the Goſpel-Miniſtry is, to kill the very root of Sin; to heal the depraved Natures of Men that be tainted and poiſoned with it. It tends indeed to curb their Luſts, and keep them from being ſo Vicious and Prophane, as otherwise they would; but its alſo appointed as a Means to heal their wretched Natures, and cure them of their Heart-plagues.
RULERS will accordingly ſee to the Incouragement and Support of the Goſpel-Miniſtry. This ſurely they will do, as knowing that in this way they are a Terror to evil workers.
AND they will do it,

1. BY promoting Learning in the Tongues and Arts. They know that ſuch Learning is
highly needful to qualifie Perſons for the Miniſtry; and that our Fathers that ſetled this Country, even in the Infancy and Poverty of it, were accordingly at charge to erect a College for Education, beyond what was to be had in Grammar Schools.
2. BY diſcountenancing the folly of People in Chooſing Miniſters according to their vain Fancies, without regard either to the Civil Law, or Scripture-qualifications.

3. BY taking care that Miniſters be not Neceſſitated to leave their Studies, to prevent the Starving of their Families. And on this I may preſume, as concluding it well known to our Rulers. (1) That the Goſpel Miniſtry ought to be Maintained, and that honourably by the People. The Lord has ordained that they that Preach the Goſpel, ſhould live of the Goſpel, 1 Cor. 9.14. He wills, that while People partake of their Spiritual Things, they ſhould partake of their Carnal things, 1 Cor. 9.11. And declares it reaſonable from the very light of Nature, and uſage of Nations, 1 Cor. 9.7. (2) Conſequently, that People ordinarily, are able to Maintain the Miniſtry among them. Being commanded ſo to do, they have ability there-unto. Were it not thus, certainly ſuch a Precept had never been given them of GOD. It is true, that reſpecting ſome Spiritual
duties required of Men, we can't argue from the Command, an ability to obey: but reſpecting any external acts of Obedience, the argument ſeems to be ſtrong, from GOD's Precept, to argue ability in People to yield Obedience. Accordingly, People ordinarily are able to Maintain and that decently and honourably, the Goſpel-Miniſtry among them. (3) That People do not ordinarily thus Maintain it. I ſpeak not this to reflect on any Place or People: but I take it to be evident to Judicious Rulers, that thus it is. (4) That GOD has authorized them to ſee that Juſtice be herein done to the Miniſtry. And, (5) That it will be for the Intereſt of People themſelves, that their Miniſters have juſt dealing in this regard from them. Rulers know that this will tend not to their Poverty, but their Proſperity. Sure I am that the Scripture thus affirms. Prov. 3.9, 10. Honour the Lord with thy ſubſtance, and with the firſt fruits of all thy increaſe. So ſhall thy barns be filled with plenty, &c. Mal. 3.10. Bring ye all the tithes in to the Store-houſe, that there may be Meat in mine houſe; and prove me now herewith, ſaith the Lord of Hoſts, if I will not open you the windows of Heaven, and pour you out a bleſſing, &c.
I paſs now to the Improvement of the Doctrine.
USE, I. Is by way of Caution.

THAT abſolute perfection be not expected from any Order of Men whatſoever. We are not in the State of Innocency, with Adam before the fall. Nor do we live among the Stars, where the proper Orbs are kept, and all the Motions regular. We live in a Curſed, and a Wicked World. Sin and Corruption, darkneſs and error have infeſted every Society of Men. Rulers, whither Civil or Eccleſiaſtical; People, whither in the State or Church, labour under the deadly fruits of the firſt Apoſtacy. There is not a Perſon among us, but often wanders out of his way. Jam. 3.2. In many things we all offend. Absolute Perfection then, is not to be expected among us. Nor ought it to be a ſtumbling-block to any, that it is not found.

THERE was not unmixed Equity in the Civil State, no, not in Solomons time. Eccl. 3.16. I ſaw under the Sun the place of Judgment, that wickedneſs was there, and the place of righteouſneſs, that iniquity was there. Nor are all things right in the Eccleſiaſtick Polity in any Age; whither among Paſtors, or People; Rulers, or Ruled. Nor may it be expected while the word holds good, in Jer. 17.9. The heart of man is deceitful above all
things, and deſperately wicked. Indeed that word, if duely thought of, will ſtain the Pride of all humane glory; and lay every Man, from the King on the Throne, to the Beggar in the Street, in the duſt, before GOD.

AGAIN, People, through Ignorance and want of Judgment, may think that amiſs in Rulers, which indeed is not ſo. Acts of Rulers may be ſometimes ill reſented, for want of knowing the true ground and reaſon of them.

AND again, Errors in Government may oft proceed from the Iniquities of People, as the moral cauſe thereof. If that be sometimes true, Delirant Reges, plectuntur Ach •• i; that is infallibly true, in Prov. 28.2. For the tranſgreſſion of a Land, many are the Princes thereof. And ſo as to other afflictive evils relating to Government.
USE, II. Is of Inſtruction & Exhortation.
ARE Rulers a Terror to evil Workers: Then,

1. WHAT will GOD Himſelf, the Governour of the World be? He is the Judge of all the Earth, Gen. 18.25. Juſtice and Judgment are the habitation of his Throne. And what will
become of wicked-workers then, when they fall into His Hand? That will be found a ſolemn Truth, in Heb. 10.31. It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living GOD. It were much better for wicked men never to have been born, than thus to fall into the Hands of this GOD.

2. RULERS then are a great bleſſing to a wretched World. Were not evil-workers terrified by Rulers, the World would ſoon be Uninhabitable. Men would not be able to live one among another. They would be in an higher degree than now they are, as deſcribed in Hab. 1.14. As the Fiſhes of the Sea, devouring one another. Tyranny its ſelf is leſs bad than Anarchy. But Rulers ruling in the fear of GOD, are indeed great bleſſings. Unto their Rule, under GOD, is the Peace and Tranquillity of a People very much owing.

3. OUR Rulers then, will mind their Character, given in my Text. Its the inſpired Apoſtle that ſaith, Rulers are a Terror to evil works. A great part of this Aſſembly are Rulers. Will each One ever bear in Mind, ever make proper and beneficial reflections on this their Character; Rulers are a Terror, not to good, but to evil works.

4. THANK we GOD for Rulers. Let them be accounted among the rich, tho' but common bleſſings of a Land. Rulers ruling in the fear of G0D; doing Juſtice & Judgment; ſeeking the wealth of their People, are a great and a rich bleſſing. Theſe are the Shields of the Earth, Pſal. 47.9. They bear up the Pillars of a Land, as in Pſal. 75.3. What a Chaos of confuſion, and field of blood would the World preſently be, were it not for Government. Let Rulers then be acknowledged as great bleſſings to our Land.

5. LET all Pray for them, that they may ever be a Terror to evil-workers. This is the Preceptive Will of GOD, in 1 Tim. 2.2. Let Prayer be made for Kings, and for all that be in Authority. Hitherto few if any People in the World have been favoured by GOD, in reſpect of Government, as New-England has been. Let GOD be ſought, for the continuance of this Favour. And let none contribute by their ingratitude, to the forfeiture of it.
I conclude only with two words, which have evidently much of awe and ſolemnity in them. And they are directed to the two conſtituent parts of this great Aſſembly, viz. Rulers, and Ruled, And,

1. WILL our Rulers think how they repreſent the very Perſon of the Incarnate SON of GOD. That Sacred Perſon is verily repreſented by You. Its His Authority you are inveſted with; for He is not only the Head of the Church, but the head over all things to the Church, Eph. 1.22. All Power is given to Him as Mediator. And with His Kingly Power, by Participation, Civil Rulers are inveſted. On this account they are called gods, in Pſal. 82.6.

ITS true, it is ſo, and more than barely ſo, reſpecting Eccleſiaſtical Rulers: They alſo repreſent His very Perſon, and that not in one only, but in all His Offices, Prophetical, Prieſtly, and Kingly. I do not ſay, That they repreſent His perſon in all Parts of all His Offices, but in all His Offices. His Prophetical Office, they repreſent, in Speaking from GOD unto the People; His Prieſtly Office, in Praying for them; and His Kingly, in Ruling of them. Accordingly we read, as in Joh.20. 21. —As my Father hath ſent me, ſo ſend I you. Heb. 13.17. Obey them that have the rule ever you. Mat. 28.19. Go and teach all Nations. James 5. 14. Let the Elders of the Church Pray for him. Thus do they repreſent the Perſon of CHRIST. Nor are their Commiſſions leſs Authentick, but leſs
Mediate from Soveraign Power, than thoſe of Them in Civil Government. And it may accordingly ſeem ſtrange, that any that be acquainted with the Bible, ſhould either in their Prints, or Practice, aſſign them their Place at the Peoples feet.

But when Rulers, whither Civil or Eccleſiaſtick, think, whoſe glorious Perſon is repreſented by them, How ſolemn will be the thought! What awful impreſſions will it make on their Spirits! What manner of Perſons will they think themſelves obliged to be in an holy unblamable Conversation! None in the World are under ſuch ſolemn and ſtrong ties, as theſe, to regard & obey that Precept, in Eph. 5.15. See then that ye walk circumſpectly. Beware of ſo much as a wry Step, left the infinite Perſon repreſented by you, be thereby reflected on, and diſhonoured; leaſt His Great Name be blasphemed by your means.

2. LET People, who make the other conſtituent Part of this Aſſembly, regard you, Civil Rulers, as being of this Character. Know, that they repreſent the Perſon, and are cloathed with the Authority of GOD the SON. They are on this account termed, as in Psai. 82.6. The Children of the Moſt High. Thus then regard them, and deport your ſelves accordingly toward them. And,

1. DO not conclude their acts in Government to be neceſſarily amiſs, becauſe you can't preſently ſee the ground and reaſon of them. Things done may be reaſonable, juſt and equal, tho' every eye can't preſently diſcern the reaſonableneſs, equality, and juſtice of them.

2. WITH-hold not the reſpect and honour from them, which is their due, in regard of their Character. Honour them, as repreſenting the Perſon, and cloathed with the Authority above mentioned. Honour is their due, and accordingly they ſhould have it, Deut. 5.16.

3. CHEARFULLY Pay them their Tribute what is owing to them, on the account of the continual Service they do for you. Unto this Justice it ſelf obliges you: and the ground to enforce to the doing Juſtly in this regard the Apoſtle has given us, in Rom. 13.6. having ſaid that Tribute was paid to Civil Rulers, he gives the ground of it, viz. For they are God's Miniſters, attending continually on this very thing.

SINCE the Compoſing the Diſcourſe above, having heard the Melancholly News from Home, of the DEATH of Sir WILLIAM ASHHURST, a Lover of, and Benefactor to our Country; Yea, to the Britiſh Kingdom, where he had his Reſidence: I take this Occaſion, on behalf I of this Obliged People, to expreſs our ſad Reſentment of, and Lamentations for ſo great a Publick Loſs: And earneſt deſires of a continued Succeſſion of his NAME, in his Family of Worthy Patriots; whoſe fragrant Names shall be famous in our Iſrael, for their Worthy Deeds, as His has been, till Time ſhall be no more.
